Time Approximate.

"A two-and-a-half hour black and white film about German village life in 1913 with no music in the soundtrack won top prize at the Cannes Film Festival.

The German director was among the favourites for the Palme d’Or four years ago for his enigmatic thriller Hidden, which became an international art house favorite but lost out to the Belgian Dardenne brothers.

Like Hidden, The White Ribbon is a complex and demanding whodunit without a straightforward resolution. After the premiere, Haneke told The Times: “I see my films as a ski jump. It’s up to the spectator to decide whether to take off.” Critics have interpreted the film as an investigation of the roots of German fascism, but Haneke said that he intended it to have a much wider resonance as a warning about how any absolute value system leads eventually to terrorism. " - Ben Hoyle, Correspondent in Cannes

Alternative Film Guide


Director of Hidden, Director of Cache, Iconic Director in Person at the HFA for a showing of Funny Games, Michael Haneke's The White Ribbon has been called by some, his best film to date. Please be prepared for a Haneke film before RSVP'ing to this event! We are in for a difficult, depressing, enigmatic experience.

Followed by lighthearted discussion at The Friendly Toast
item.how_to_find_us: John will hold a Meetup sign using a white ribbon at the end of the film, if anyone is left alive for the fun discussion at The Friendly Toast
